oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Use of Animal-Based Parameters to Evaluate Tie-Stall Design and Stockmanship on Dairy Farms in Ontario
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Zurbrigg, K.
Millman, S.
Anderson, N.
Kelton, D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: lameness
mastitis
Injury
fecal contamination
stockmanship
tie-stall design
cattle welfare
husbandry
animal welfare
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Injury, poor claw health, lameness and mastitis due to fecal contamination are negative results from inadequate stockmanship or tie-stall design. These problems affect cattle welfare and increase the probability of premature culling, lost production and negative attitudes by the public toward the dairy industry. Animal-based parameters can be used to measure the cow's response to management choices. This information can be used to evaluate husbandry choices and improve animal welfare and productivity.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2004; 193
